supporting.text: According to the order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS), multiplication takes precedence over addition, so 3 + 3 * 4 equals 3 + 12, which is 15, not 3 * 5 (15).

attacks.text: According to the order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS), multiplication takes precedence over addition, so 3 + 3 * 4 equals 3 + 12, which is 15, not 3 * 5 (15).
The equation 3 + 3 * 4 = 3 * 5 holds true numerically (both sides equal 15), even if the order of operations is not explicitly followed.
The claim is about the validity of the equation under standard arithmetic rules, not just numerical coincidence. The order of operations must be respected for the equation to hold.

supporting.text: The left side of the equation simplifies to 15 (3 + 12), while the right side is also 15 (3 * 5), but the equation is not mathematically valid because the operations are not equivalent in form.

attacks.text: The left side of the equation simplifies to 15 (3 + 12), while the right side is also 15 (3 * 5), but the equation is not mathematically valid because the operations are not equivalent in form.
The equation is mathematically valid because both sides evaluate to the same numerical value (15), regardless of the operations used.
Mathematical validity requires not only equal values but also equivalent forms or logical equivalence, which this equation lacks.

supporting.text: The equation incorrectly implies that addition and multiplication are interchangeable without parentheses, which violates standard arithmetic rules.

attacks.text: The equation incorrectly implies that addition and multiplication are interchangeable without parentheses, which violates standard arithmetic rules.
The equation 3 + 3 * 4 = 3 * 5 is actually correct because multiplication has higher precedence than addition, so the left side evaluates to 3 + 12 = 15, and the right side evaluates to 15.
The claim that the equation violates standard arithmetic rules is misleading because it ignores the well-established order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS).

supporting.text: Mathematically, the equation misrepresents the relationship between addition and multiplication, as the left side requires two operations (addition and multiplication) while the right side only requires one (multiplication).

attacks.text: Mathematically, the equation misrepresents the relationship between addition and multiplication, as the left side requires two operations (addition and multiplication) while the right side only requires one (multiplication).
The equation 3 + 3 * 4 = 3 * 5 is false because the left side evaluates to 15 (3 + 12) while the right side evaluates to 15 as well, making the equation true.
The left side evaluates to 15 only if the multiplication is performed before addition, which is the standard order of operations. Without this rule, the equation could be misinterpreted.
The standard order of operations (PEMDAS/BODMAS) is universally accepted in mathematics, so the interpretation without it is irrelevant in practice.
